last_post.content:
The book »Algorithmen & Zeichen« with essays from Frieder Nake is now available as open access! The book was edited by Jan Distelmeyer, Sophie Ehrmanntraut and myself. It contains 18 texts (15 on German, 3 on English) from Frieder Nake — as well as an excerpt of his artistic work.

If you are into media theory, computer science, computer art and / or UX design: this book might be something for you!

last_post.content:
History of distributed digital communication networks; https://www.rand.org/about/history/baran.html

"Paul Baran conceived of the Internet and digital packet switching, the Internet's underlying data communications technology. His concepts are still employed today; just the terms are different. His seminal work first appeared in a series of RAND studies published between 1960 and 1962 and then finally in the tome “On Distributed Communications,” published in 1964."

@dragfyre @Chris Trottier Advantages of Friendica groups over gup.pe groups:

Gup.pe is centralised because there is exactly one instance. Friendica is fully decentralised, and you can create forums on any instance that allows you to register an account.

Friendica groups can be read without joining them first. Gup.pe groups can't.

Friendica groups allow the pre-joining post backlog to be read. Gup.pe groups don't.

Friendica groups have to be created manually as user accounts. This means there's always at least one human behind each group which means Friendica groups can be moderated directly from within by users with special privileges. AFAIK, additional moderations can be appointed. None of this applies to gup.pe groups which are created automatically.

Private Friendica groups with limited access are possible. The same isn't possible on gup.pe.

Gup.pe only lists 50 groups. Friendica lists all of them.

Good morning! The weather is looking fine today. Yesterday turned out a bit too windy for my liking.

I enjoy taking potshots at BlueSky. First, it's easy. Second, in difference to ActivityPub, I'm not invested enough, to feel any desire to fix it. So call me posting about BlueSky a form of deflection.

Anyway, today's look at the AT Protocol: How can I extend it? The answer is surprisingly simple; They reinvented the wheel. Let's hope they find enough volunteers to build the tooling they want to offer good developer experience.

For example, json-ld DX is not great, but it exists. Also these people have been at it for at least 12 years, if my date lookup works. Their mailing list speaks of meetings once a month. So yes not great, but inspiring.

Anyway, today's look at the AT Protocol: How can I extend it? The answer is surprisingly simple; They reinvented the wheel. Let's hope they find enough volunteers to build the tooling they want to offer good developer experience.

For example, json-ld DX is not great, but it exists. Also these people have been at it for at least 12 years, if my date lookup works. Their mailing list speaks of meetings once a month. So yes not great, but inspiring.

If you want to set up a Fediverse group (a.k.a., "Public Forum") on Friendica, follow these steps:

1. Create an account on Friendica. I prefer doing this on https://venera.social

2. Go to Settings > Advanced account types

3. Select "Community Forum" (a.k.a., group). Make sure Public forum is selected.

4. Click "Save settings".

If you want to see what a Fediverse group looks like, visit here: https://venera.social/profile/fediversenews

Also see screenshot.

title: Is it possible to color each integer greater than 1 with either red, green, or blue so that all 3 colors are used, and for every two inte...

last_post.content:
Messing about with #graphviz, as one does.

This shows a four-coloring of the integers of the form \( 2^x3^y \) when there is an edge between any two of a, 2a, 3a, and 4a. A rule that works is \( C(2^x3^y) = x - y \pmod 4 \). We can extend that rule to all integers because those with different odd factors greater than 3 won't have connecting edges.

Is is the only such #coloring of this #graph, up to isomorphism? It seems unlikely and yet... there's not a lot of freedom here, everything up to 12 is obviously fixed.

https://www.quora.com/Is-it-possible-to-color-each-integer-greater-than-1-with-either-red-green-or-blue-so-that-all-3-colors-are-used-and-for-every-two-integers-x-and-y-colored-in-two-different-colors-the-integer-x-y-I-colored-with-the
